item.title: #TIL : Using web proxy to bypass firewalls
item.description: Using web proxy to bypass firewalls Someday, you will be blocked by a firewall while trying crawling or accessing some website. The reason is they block your IP address from accessing the server. One solution is using a web proxy (http proxy, socks4 or socks5) to bypass the firewall, by adding the middle-man server between you and target. It’s a bit unsecured but you could use for https site only.

item.title: #TIL : Enable reverse proxy in CentOS
item.description: Enable reverse proxy in CentOS CentOS with SELinux enabled by default will block any http proxy connection. So you have to enable this permission. Temporary enable $ /usr/sbin/setsebool httpd_can_network_connect 1 Permanent enable $ /usr/sbin/setsebool -P httpd_can_network_connect 1

item.title: Webfonts Optimization Using Nginx
item.description: Context Everytime you decided to use a webfont on your web, you think about Google Web Fonts, which is the best CDN for webfonts at this moment. So why Google Fonts is good solution : - Have many popular and updated fonts - Global CDN - Easy UX to get started - Auto detects user’s browser then return supported font type (TTF, WOFF or WOFF2) But It’s a tracking endpoint (collect data to Google) Network latency (you have a CDN in your country) Solution We use a simple Node server and NGINX with proxy cache mod to resolve this case.
